componenttext: Uche, we don't provide specific capacity utilization levels, as it just seems to create confusion with the investors and analysts. People seem to do a straight expert extrapolation and in reality, it doesn't quite work that way. We see a continued gross margin improvement in our fiscal fourth quarter based on the non-GAAP guidance we provided 59.75% to 60.25%. And we also indicated earlier that we should get back to our prior peak gross margins of 61.6% non-GAAP over the next four quarters by the end of fiscal year '11. And that gets to the prior peak gross margins, and that's where we believe that without SST, that sort of where our business model is.

componenttext: The delivery performance from the competitors and all of these product lines, 8s, 16s and 32s. Obviously, our largest market presence is in 8-bit microcontrollers. So from a frequency standpoint, that's the most frequent place where we see that inroad happens. But you know, it affects more than just today's designs that we can switch the microchip by helping the customer take advantage of our supply, and helping them on the technical side to make the conversions. It affects their confidence about future designs as they look at future designs that can affect 8, 16 or 32 because on customers who do their designs, they want to be able to take it to production. And they want a supplier who has a manufacturing output that lines up with what they're trying to ship.

componenttext: Just Steve, you reminded us that you've given a 2010 forecast early. You're not updating that per see, but you kind of alluded to the fact that you think you will. Beat that and obviously, the March guidance kind of sets the stage. As you're looking through 2010, when you think about end demand, do you think it kind of materializes in the normal seasonal fashion beyond the March quarter and whatever share gains you get on top of that? What do you think there's end markets that are still get the rebound from the inventory depletion mode they were in?

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think we have consistently said that's across our 70,000 customers and a large amount of our business coming from distribution, we don't really can break out the end demand for you by segment. Once in a while, we have done an analysis on some sample cus
componenttext: I think we have consistently said that's across our 70,000 customers and a large amount of our business coming from distribution, we don't really can break out the end demand for you by segment. Once in a while, we have done an analysis on some sample customers during the middle of the housing bust and all of that. We can create an indicator for a short period of time. But customers move around regarding where they buy their product from. Many of them switch to distributors or CMs or whatever. So our product strategy has always been very horizontal in all of our product lines. We sell across thousands of applications, 70,000 customers and we're seeing a broad-based recovery in every geography around the world. And beyond that, we can't really give you an end market commentary. We are seeing our business grow significantly better than our competitors. I did some comparisons to SIA this time in the last two or three times also. So we're seeing significant share gains, our new product pipeline is really the best it has been in a long time because we stay committed with our resources and product designs in the last year and a half for many of our competitors laid off people and killed the product pipelines. Our lead times shorter, our customer service is excellent so customers are designing with us. So we feel a very, very strong outlook in every way we look at it.

componenttextpreview: Yes, that's primarily driven by interest rates. We've had some longer-term investments that we had made, that has rolled off and then kind of resets it to lower rates, and what we're able to invest at today, so that is the major driver. And then going for
componenttext: Yes, that's primarily driven by interest rates. We've had some longer-term investments that we had made, that has rolled off and then kind of resets it to lower rates, and what we're able to invest at today, so that is the major driver. And then going forward, I would say that we're pretty much in a flattish modes. As we generate cash where we invest at. But the investment returns at this point in time is pretty low.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Steve, there's been a lot of dislocation in your competitive environment. I'm sure some of those guys will try to come back in the marketplace. So my questions on the design cycle. Let's say you'd take a design win and then apply in sort of other product.
componenttext: Steve, there's been a lot of dislocation in your competitive environment. I'm sure some of those guys will try to come back in the marketplace. So my questions on the design cycle. Let's say you'd take a design win and then apply in sort of other product. Do you typically keep it for the life of the product? Or do you see these guys come back next year and try to get back in.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Harsh, once a customer does the design, everybody is so resource constrained these days. Where people have laid out their resources, they will contracted them out. And once the design goes in production, we really ever seen our industry design mid protect
componenttext: Harsh, once a customer does the design, everybody is so resource constrained these days. Where people have laid out their resources, they will contracted them out. And once the design goes in production, we really ever seen our industry design mid protection switch. People switch mid-protection designs only if they can acquire the product or their significant quality and other support issues. Otherwise, the design switching usually happens on subsequent design if you give the customer then it isn't to grow away from you. In this environment, when we're actually billing customers in supplying the product with competitors at a very long lead times, the companies who are designing with us and they're favoring us, they are actually making even a stronger commitment to us going forward. Forget about growing back to the other competitors, they will keep on giving us subsequent designs because they have seen cycle after cycle, Microchip with investment and inventory in short lead times continuously gaining shares is providing them with the right product, the right functionality at the right price and at the right lead times.

componenttext: It's very, very broad-based. But I did highlight many of the focus areas in the last three years, where we have introduced 400 new products in the last three years. And many of these products have been in the areas of eXtreme Low Power, but I believe our portfolio is about 60 or 70 products now. Touch Sense, which is really on five. We're gaining Touch Sense designs everywhere, USB interface, advanced graphics, high-performance analog, ethernet connectivity, RF, motor control and digital power supply. Some of these are highlighted and they're many, many more.

componenttextpreview: I would add that 32-bit designs that take about two, two and half years to get to production because they're really on the high end. And our products have been in production less than two years. So we're sure that as you're seeing right now is still from
componenttext: I would add that 32-bit designs that take about two, two and half years to get to production because they're really on the high end. And our products have been in production less than two years. So we're sure that as you're seeing right now is still from an early-stage designs, pre-introduction alpha sites and beta sites and things like that. So the real major customer ramp we will have significant high-volume designs is really still around the corner.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: If you guys end up hitting your revenue plan for this year can just remind us of when you'll start to need to add extra capacity when your utilization rates max out in terms of quarterly revenue?
componenttext: If you guys end up hitting your revenue plan for this year can just remind us of when you'll start to need to add extra capacity when your utilization rates max out in terms of quarterly revenue?

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Again, we don't break out utilization like I said earlier, but we are continuously, incrementally adding fab capacity, bottlenecks here and there. The mix today of the products and the technology is different than the mix we had two years ago when we were
componenttext: Again, we don't break out utilization like I said earlier, but we are continuously, incrementally adding fab capacity, bottlenecks here and there. The mix today of the products and the technology is different than the mix we had two years ago when we were at the prior peak. That's why the utilization plays funny games and you guys get the wrong extrapolation because over two years, as you come back to the same peak revenue things are different and their different processes and  more advanced processes. So we are continuously, incrementally and slowly adding to the capacity to provide product for our customers at very, very short lead times. So in this coming year, as the business continues to grow, we'll be incrementally adding capital in the range that you'll see in a low capital from Microchip over the years.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess just one additional comment on that for everybody on the call, is we have lots of floor space to grow into in the fabs and in our assembly and test operations, so it's really just equipment. And we've tried to take advantage of low-cost opportunit
componenttext: I guess just one additional comment on that for everybody on the call, is we have lots of floor space to grow into in the fabs and in our assembly and test operations, so it's really just equipment. And we've tried to take advantage of low-cost opportunities in the marketplace during this downturn.

componenttext: 80%, 90% of our products are still available in our fairly relatively short lead time. You always exemptions where it's a special package or a given day where a large demand came in. And those exceptions are a little more than usual now than they were nine months ago, but Microchip's lead times are really still pretty, the best in the industry.What I would like to do operator now, is to go to the next section where we will talk about SST. First, we'll make some prepared remarks and after that we'll reopen it up for questions and will take questions regarding SST. And in the second question section you can also add any of the remaining questions somebody may have regarding the earnings call.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: As most of you are aware by now, earlier today we announced the definitive agreement to acquire Silicon Storage Technology Inc. or otherwise known as SST. We're excited about this acquisition and we would now like to give you a brief overview of who SST i
componenttext: As most of you are aware by now, earlier today we announced the definitive agreement to acquire Silicon Storage Technology Inc. or otherwise known as SST. We're excited about this acquisition and we would now like to give you a brief overview of who SST is, why we decided to acquire them, how we plan to handle the financial reporting for the various SST businesses and then summarize the overall transaction. So let's start with an overview of who SST is. SST is a global leader in embedded flash technology and in licensing of these technologies. SST also has several other businesses nested within the company including Serial, Parallel and Specialty Flash Memories, 8051 microcontrollers and NAND controllers. NAND drives that provide solid state storage, power amplifiers and low noise amplifiers for Wi-Fi applications. SST is headquartered in Sunnyvale, California and has 574 employees worldwide. SST has approximately $180 million in cash and liquid trading securities on their balance sheet and no debt. We see a compelling strategic rationale to acquire SST for the following reasons: First, their proprietary Superflash technology is a critical building block technology for advanced microcontrollers. For example, this Superflash technology is licensed by most major foundries and microcontroller OEM. This acquisition secure us critical embedded flash technology for Microchip's core, Microcontroller business and it also enables us to get earlier access to advance technologies versus waiting until their in production at the foundries. This acquisition also gives us the ability to customize technology variants that would give us an advantage over competing technologies. Second, SST adds a strong patent portfolio to Microchip's intellectual property portfolio. SST is over 360 graphic patterns and over 180 patents that are pending. And third, we would add 8051 microcontrollers and NAND controllers to our microcontroller portfolio, NAND controllers essentially are specialized microcontrollers for a given application.Now let's move to the financial reporting plan. The Licensing business, 8051 microcontrollers and NAND controllers will be consolidated into Microchip's financial reporting of continuing operations. We plan to continue investing in Superflash technology, consistent with enabling our technology needs and growing the Licensing business. We plan to rationalize the Serial, Parallel and Specialty Flash Memory businesses consistent with supporting and growing the Licensing business and emulating Microchip's high margin Serial EEPROM business model. We will treat the memory business model as an asset held for sale until the rationalizing is complete. And we plan to divest the NAND drive and Wi-Fi amplifier businesses, and we'll hold them as assets held for sale.Finally, let me provide you with a transaction summary. A $2.85 per share acquisition price translates to a transaction value of $275 million. However, once you account for SST's $180 million in cash and liquid trading and securities, the net transaction value is approximately $95 million. We expect the blended, non-GAAP operating margins to be excellent after we complete the planned divestitures and rationalize the Memory business. We expect the transaction to be accretive on a non-GAAP basis in the first quarter full quarter after the transaction closes, and expect to close the transaction in the second calendar quarter of 2010. A presentation for the key points we have reviewed with you today will be available from our website after this conference call. And with that, we would be happy to take your questions about the SST acquisition.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question will come from the side of James Schneider with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess broader on the capital allocation front, this is, I believe the fifth acquisition you've made in the last 18 months or so. Could you just comment on  your broader strategy for capital allocation whether you have more of a divided to the acquisitio
componenttext: I guess broader on the capital allocation front, this is, I believe the fifth acquisition you've made in the last 18 months or so. Could you just comment on  your broader strategy for capital allocation whether you have more of a divided to the acquisitions right now of use of cash but rather than dividend increases, which have been a little bit measure of late?

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our dividend is still one of the highest in the industry. And as analysts, you guys should make up your mind. We have heard people say that the dividend was too high just two or three quarters ago and then for a very short period of time, we could not cov
componenttext: Our dividend is still one of the highest in the industry. And as analysts, you guys should make up your mind. We have heard people say that the dividend was too high just two or three quarters ago and then for a very short period of time, we could not cover the dividend during the global financial crisis and saying why you're paying such a high dividend. Other said their dividend will be cut, we were the one company that didn't cut it, maintained the dividend now we're slowly growing it again, still keeping it at industry high. And yes, for the last 18 months we have done five acquisitions, but most of them had been quite small. This is the largest acquisition, which will use about $95 million to $100 million. Many others have been really single-digits to low single-digits kind of numbers. So our strategy with this acquisitions is elbow out with each and every acquisition, we are slowly and steadily elbowing out to the adjacent sockets and under microcontroller or helping act to a microcontroller whether it add Wi-Fi capability to a microcontroller with ZeroG, whether it added touchscreen with the Hampshire acquisition, whether it give us the world-class C compilers with the software acquisition we did. And in this particular case, the Superflash technology, nearly 4 billion plus microcontrollers a year are built on SST flash technology, majority of our competitors and major foundries have licensed their technology. So we believe that, that technology in our hands will have significant advantage to get advance leading access to that.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: And maybe if I could ask a follow-up, specifically on SST, if you look at the designs you're at in the marketplace out there, how often does your microcontrollers appear alongside SST memory products and designs? And you expect you could also get some add
componenttext: And maybe if I could ask a follow-up, specifically on SST, if you look at the designs you're at in the marketplace out there, how often does your microcontrollers appear alongside SST memory products and designs? And you expect you could also get some additional cross-sell opportunities in addition to the advantage you mentioned before?

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: The SST memory products are not at all competitive with the Memory business we have. We make a Serial EE [Serial EEPROM] memory which is very, very low density, one 1K memory to one megabit memory. SST products are more in the area either there's serial f
componenttext: The SST memory products are not at all competitive with the Memory business we have. We make a Serial EE [Serial EEPROM] memory which is very, very low density, one 1K memory to one megabit memory. SST products are more in the area either there's serial flash or parallel flash, so their really relatively different market. We have not seen these products very much around the microcontroller, although when you get into large customers, large blue-chip customers they use everything, then we'll find some opportunities. But the goal with the SST business and the memory is not necessarily to ship more of those memory products around microcontrollers but to actually rationalize the large memory business so it makes a high profits like our Serial Memory business.

componenttext: And our next question will come from the side of Doug Freedman from Broadpoint.

componenttext: I think its a detailed question that we don't have a precise answer today. This acquisition is supposed to close in early April approximately, so we have the next two months to completely figure that out. So as we are closing this acquisition, will hold another conference call and give you a guidance on really how the total sales and model would look like. Right now, you can basically assume that Microchip is not going to jeopardize its continuing gross and operating margin business that we have today. So the businesses we will keep above the line would really meet Microchip's metrics.

componenttext: On SST, again like the previous caller you'll have to forgive my lack of knowledge on it, but it appear to be predominantly like 80% or so were exposed, like consumer PC handsets, is that the case? And is that what you're going to target in the future?

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the answer is yes. They have a high exposure into the consumer segment than into the PC segment. As Steve mentioned, I think what we want to understand is how we can find the aspects of the business that have margin characteristics that we would l
componenttext: I think the answer is yes. They have a high exposure into the consumer segment than into the PC segment. As Steve mentioned, I think what we want to understand is how we can find the aspects of the business that have margin characteristics that we would like and that's really where we will focus our energies on.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me expand on that. Take the Microcontroller Touch business, competitors focus on handsets. We have a large touch business with 500 customers in production, largely outside the handsets making very high margins. Serial EE Business, most of our competit
componenttext: Let me expand on that. Take the Microcontroller Touch business, competitors focus on handsets. We have a large touch business with 500 customers in production, largely outside the handsets making very high margins. Serial EE Business, most of our competitors take the low margins business as in PC consumer whatever we have a highly profitable good margins Serial EE business. So this is the Microchip strength and skill, where we know how to draw the diamond out of the rough and that's what we got to do with this business.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010

componenttext: And our next question will come from the side of Harsh Kumar with Morgan Keegan.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010

componenttext: I'm also not very familiar with SSTI, are you a customer of the licensing technology of Superflash from them? And also, in the future as you complete acquisition, would you let your competitors use that technology? If you can answer that.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I can answer that. Microchip uses SST technology in many of our products that we developed at the foundries. Microchip had not directly licensed the SST technology for using our fab but we were in negotiations to do so. In this way, we just own it,
componenttext: Well, I can answer that. Microchip uses SST technology in many of our products that we developed at the foundries. Microchip had not directly licensed the SST technology for using our fab but we were in negotiations to do so. In this way, we just own it, we don't have to license it.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: And would you let your competitors use it in the future?
componenttext: And would you let your competitors use it in the future?

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. We will keep the Licensing business as a standalone element business where their goal would be to really grow the Licensing business and license the rest of the foundries and take the advance technologies. And many of our hard-core competitors in mic
componenttext: Yes. We will keep the Licensing business as a standalone element business where their goal would be to really grow the Licensing business and license the rest of the foundries and take the advance technologies. And many of our hard-core competitors in microcontrollers are using SST flash technology and we will not limit that access to that technology to keep the licensing business pure. It's very high margin, 100% gross margin in the Licensing business. So the goal is, that is the core business in this company and we will help grow it. We have plenty of other avenues to compete with our competitors. We beat them in architecture, we beat them on designs, we beat them on cost, we beat them on service, we beat them on design wins. We don't need to limit their access through technology, we will not do that.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010

componenttext: Steve, let me just start up by asking you, are you, from an investment standpoint, you are now quite frankly diverse, that is defining to the Memory business? And it's a product that collaborates with the microcontroller but it is still a memory business. What do you think you can do with this business such that investors do not, that's wanted [ph] (1:53:32) by a multiple, given that in a typical Memory business you have all the issues about volatility, and on the line business model you have issues about margin structure. So I know you say it's going to meet the Microchip metrics but any more ways you can assure us that this will not bring a multiple depressing attributes to your business? That's just something I want to...

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Uche, you know we signed this deal at midnight. And answering those kind of questions, there are employees involved, there are customers involved, there are partners involved and I think you have to be a bit more patient as we develop the integration plan
componenttext: Uche, you know we signed this deal at midnight. And answering those kind of questions, there are employees involved, there are customers involved, there are partners involved and I think you have to be a bit more patient as we develop the integration plans and more precisely can tell you what goes into the continuing business and what falls below, we're giving you in some indication. Microchip has been in the memory business for 20 years and never lost money. We're the most consistent, high-margin, profitable business in memory and non-memory, so we know how to do it. Be patient and give us some credit, and if you don't, then so be it.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Steve, in terms of technically understanding what Superflash really brings. Is this really more about high density, lower power embedded flash? And I just wanted to, if you can, give us a little bit more insight as to how these product technically stands
componenttext: Steve, in terms of technically understanding what Superflash really brings. Is this really more about high density, lower power embedded flash? And I just wanted to, if you can, give us a little bit more insight as to how these product technically stands up against you basic floating kit [ph] (1:55:06) non-flash products used by other people? That will just be something.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: SST's flash is a much smaller cell size on a given technology than these flash we're doing internally. Now the flash that were done inside, is significantly more reliable. We are one of the only competitors, I believe, there maybe always others and then w
componenttext: SST's flash is a much smaller cell size on a given technology than these flash we're doing internally. Now the flash that were done inside, is significantly more reliable. We are one of the only competitors, I believe, there maybe always others and then we say only there's the risk of being wrong. Our internal flash doesn't require added connection to go into even the most complexed and reliability sensitive applications like automotive. Some of the SST flash applications in automotive, for example, require an added collection mechanism. So our internal technology leads in reliability, leads in accident reliability, low power and other stuff. So we address the market inside with our products which have those characteristics. They're often lower density products, they're often low-powered products and other things. Now microcontroller market is very, very diverse. Everybody doesn't need low power, everybody doesn't need low-density, some need high-density but they also need reliability for. So SST flash, definitely more microcontrollers in the world shipped on SST flash than probably in any other technology, we can probably safely say that. So having that in our hands, giving us early access to that technology, being able to use it inside, as well as at foundries and being able to create variants of that technology for our own competitive advantage, I think, is a significant benefit for a long-term Microcontroller business.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: And if I would add to that, I think you know, as we push up and out in terms of the microcontroller market, we continue to add larger microcontroller products, more complex microcontroller products that have larger amounts of memory. Superflash will becom
componenttext: And if I would add to that, I think you know, as we push up and out in terms of the microcontroller market, we continue to add larger microcontroller products, more complex microcontroller products that have larger amounts of memory. Superflash will become an increasing part of how those products get deployed. And the strength of our internal technologies remains the strength for the large percentage of our smaller to medium size microcontrollers.

componenttext: I haven't heard any competitors say that their technology is not simple additions to standard CMOS, I think that's a clichÃ©. componenttext: As I answered in an earlier question, I think when people are involved, the personnels are involve, officers are involved, it's just way too early after having signed this deal midnight. It will take about two months to close the acquisition so by the time we close this acquisition, we should be able to give you pretty good indication of really where we're looking at.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: You're correct that SST is a fabless company. We will not be migrating SST's products into our fabs. Obviously, their core business is a licensing business. Beyond that, they have a large Memory business and we have spoken about most of that Memory busine
componenttext: You're correct that SST is a fabless company. We will not be migrating SST's products into our fabs. Obviously, their core business is a licensing business. Beyond that, they have a large Memory business and we have spoken about most of that Memory business is that technologies and lithographies is that we're not capable of running in our fabs because those are way too most law [ph] (2:02:10) agreements. So they run at the foundries and we will continue to run them at the foundries. And then there are or some other businesses, there is small Microcontroller business 8051, a small NAND controller business and others, they're all running at foundries and there's just probably not enough economies to bring them inside.

componenttext: Many of the PICs/dsPIC and our 32-bit products already use the SST technology. Foundries give you a standard technology, so it's really hard to get a variant out of that And Microchip's comparative differentiation and high margins and all that run by -- we travel where other people don't.

componenttext: Well, I am not setting at the numbers that you may be setting. So last reported number were $9.5 million licensing business in calendar quarter third. headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Microchip Technology Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] At this time, I would like to turn the call over to Microchip's Chief Financial Officer, Eric Bjornholt. Please go ahead, sir.
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Microchip Technology Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] At this time, I would like to turn the call over to Microchip's Chief Financial Officer, Eric Bjornholt. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good morning, everybody. I want to apologize, I guess we were having some trouble with the IR Page on our website, and so we are working diligently to get that updated. But we wanted to start the call and hopefully that gets up and running
componenttext: Thank you, and good morning, everybody. I want to apologize, I guess we were having some trouble with the IR Page on our website, and so we are working diligently to get that updated. But we wanted to start the call and hopefully that gets up and running here shortly. So during the course of this conference call, we will be making projections and other forward-looking statements regarding future events or the future financial performance of the Company. We wish to caution you that such statements or predictions and that actual events or results may differ materially. We refer you to our press release of today, as well as our recent filings with the SEC that identify important risk factors that may impact Microchip's business and results of operations. In attendance with me today are Steve Sanghi, Microchipâ€™s President and CEO; Ganesh Moorthy, Executive Vice President and COO; Gordon Parnell, Vice President, Business Development and Investor Relations.We will conduct today's conference call in two separate parts. The first part of the call will be our normal earnings call, followed by a question-and-answer session. And the second part of today's call, we will summarize our announced acquisition of SST, and then hold a separate question and answer session relating to the acquisition. For our normal earnings call, I will comment on our third quarter fiscal 2010 financial performance, and Steve and Ganesh will then give their comments on the results, discuss the current business environment, discuss our guidance for the March quarter and update other pertinent matters regarding our business. We will then be available to respond to specific investor and analyst questions. Again, please hold any questions related to the acquisition of SST until you are prompted to queue up.Net sales for the December quarter were $250.1 million, up approximately 10.3% from net sales of $226.7 million in the immediately preceding quarter, and up 30.1% from net sales of $192.2 million in the December 2008 quarter. On a geographic basis, revenue in the Americas was up 6.1% in the December quarter, Europe was up 10.2% and Asia was up 12.4%. Asia continues to be our largest geographic region, representing 52.3% of sales in the December quarter. The Americas were 23.7% of sales and Europe was 24% of sales. These measurements are based on where the product is delivered for manufacturing purposes for our customers, but does not necessarily represent where design activity is taking place or where the end product consumption is occurring. We are continuing to include information on our press release on various GAAP and non-GAAP measures. We have posted a full GAAP to non-GAAP reconciliation on our Investor Relations page of our website at www.microchip.com, which we believe you will find useful when comparing GAAP and non-GAAP results.Non-GAAP net income for the third quarter of fiscal year 2010 was $70.1 million or $0.38 per diluted share, an increase of 31.2% from non-GAAP net income of $53.2 million or $0.29 per diluted share in the immediately preceding quarter. The after-tax impact on the December 2009 quarterly earnings that have been excluded from our non-GAAP results include: $8.5 million from a favorable tax settlement with the IRS; $7.7 million in share-based compensation expense; $1 million in non-cash interest expense associated with our convertible debt; and $0.5 million in charges associated with our acquisition activities. GAAP net income was $69.4 million in the December quarter or $0.37 per diluted share. The favorable impact on GAAP EPS from the settlement with the IRS was $.045 and will not be a recurring item in the March 2009 quarter. I will now go through the some of the operating results for the December quarter. I will be referring to gross margin and operating expense information on a non-GAAP basis prior to the effect of share-based compensation and acquisition-related expenses.Gross margins were 59% in the December quarter, compared to 55.5% in the September quarter. The 350 basis point quarterly increase in gross profit margin was driven by a variety of factors, including higher production activity in our factories and continued cost reduction efforts from our global manufacturing operations. With the increase in revenue, we were able to achieve operating leverage on the business, with total operating expenses of 26.2% of sales in the December quarter, compared to 27.7% in the prior quarter. Research and development costs were $27.2 million, representing 10.9% of sales. Sales in general and administrative expenses were $38.4 million, representing 15.3% of sales. Our non-GAAP operating expenses as a percentage of sales were at approximately the same level in December 2009 quarter as they were in September 2008 quarter, which was Microchip's peak earnings quarter. The December operating expenses includes a substantial portion of all the cuts that we took in our employee compensation programs during the global financial crisis, and the forecast that we have provided for the March 2010 quarter includes the full run rate of these programs. On a full GAAP basis, gross margins including share-based compensation and acquisition-related expenses were 58.4%. Total operating expenses were $73.4 million or 29.4% of sales, and include share-based compensation of $7.6 million and acquisition-related expenses of $0.3 million. On a non-GAAP basis, the tax rate for the December quarter was 13.4%. The GAAP effective tax rate for the December quarter was 0.7%. The difference in the GAAP and non-GAAP tax rates was driven from an $8.5 million favorable settlement with the IRS related to fiscal years 2002 through 2004, as well as the higher tax rate that applies to the non-cash interest expense on our convertible debt. Our tax rate is impacted by the mix of geographical profits and the percentage of our cash that is invested in tax-advantaged securities. We expect our going forward, non-GAAP tax rate to be between 12.5% and 13%. The dividend declared today of $0.341 per share we paid on March 4, 2010, to shareholders of record on February 18, 2010. The cash payment associated with this dividend will be approximately $62.9 million. Moving onto the balance sheet, Microchip's inventory balance at December 31, 2009, was $112.8 million, representing approximately 99 days. Inventory on Microchip's balance sheet increased by $4.3 million or three days and days of inventory at our distributors increased to 40 days, compared to 35 days at the end of the prior quarter. I would like to remind you that Microchip recognizes its distribution revenue on a sell-through basis in its worldwide distribution channel. At the end of the December quarter, the combined inventory on Microchip's balance sheet and its distributors was 139 days, which is in the lower range of our historical averages. During the December quarter, we aggressively increased our manufacturing output so we can continue to satisfy the needs of our customers, by providing industry best lead times. We expect inventory days in our balance sheet in the March quarter to be about flat. The increases in our production output will have an ongoing positive impact from Microchip's gross margin percentage. At December 31, our receivables were $113.8 million, an increase of $7.1 million or 6.7% from the balance as of the September quarter. Receivable balances are in great condition with excellent payment performance continuing from our customers. Over the past year, we have not had any significant bad debt writeoffs in our business. We continue to closely monitor customer activity to ensure we are protecting the receivable assets on our balance sheet. As of December 31, Microchip's cash and total investment position was approximately $1.5 billion. Our cash generation from the business was $89.4 million, prior to the payment of a $62.5 million dividends. Our cash generation continues to be strong, and our total cash and investment position is projected to grow again in the March 2010 quarter. Capital spending was approximately $18.7 million for the December quarter and our fiscal 2010 capital expenditure forecast is currently $50 million. We are investing in equipments, support the revenue growth of our new products and technologies and are also taking advantage of low-cost equipment opportunities in the marketplace that will position us well for future growth. Depreciation expense for the December quarter was $21.7 million, which was flat to depreciation in the September quarter. I will now ask Ganesh to give us comments on the performance of the business in the December quarter. Ganesh?

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Eric, and good morning, everyone. I will now comment on the individual product lines. All three of our product lines, microcontrollers, analog and serial EEPROMs [ph] delivered outstanding growth in the December quarter. We continue to see the
componenttext: Thank you, Eric, and good morning, everyone. I will now comment on the individual product lines. All three of our product lines, microcontrollers, analog and serial EEPROMs [ph] delivered outstanding growth in the December quarter. We continue to see the results of our strategy to stay invested in our new product development and demand creation resources during the global recession. By employing a shared sacrifice to cut costs instead of resorting to mass layoffs, we believe we are seeing the continuation of differentiated revenue growth and operating profit results. Let me now take a closer look at each of product lines, starting with microcontrollers. Our Microcontroller business delivered superb results, and was up a strong 10% on a sequential basis and up 30% from the year-ago quarter. The December quarter was also the third consecutive quarter of double-digit sequential growth for the Microcontroller business. Flash microcontrollers represented 81.3% of our Microcontroller business in the December quarter. Our 8-bit Microcontroller business had another excellent quarter, as all segments of our 8-bit product lines experienced very strong growth. Our 16-bit Microcontroller business achieved another record for quarterly revenue, with strong sequential growth of 10% building upon the 49% sequential growth we had last quarter. 16-bit microcontrollers also grew over 101% from the year-ago quarter. New customers and new designs go into production continued to help drive growth as a number of volume 16-bit customers grew by 239 customers to 2,289. Our 32-bit microcontroller product line meanwhile continues to make good progress, with 44% sequential growth albeit from a smaller base, building upon the 56% sequential growth we had last quarter. We now have 173 32-bit microcontroller customers in volume production. Moving to development tools, we had another record quarter, with 41,492 development tools shipped in the December quarter. The third consecutive quarter of record development tool sales. As you have seen from our growth in recent quarters, development tool sales are in excellent leading a indicator of continued strong design and activity, and acceptance of our solutions by our customers. And the continued strength of record development tool sales should bode well for future growth.Now moving to the Analog products, our Analog business also delivered outstanding results, with very strong sequential growth of 14.1% and 40% growth versus the year-ago quarter to achieve record high revenues. This also marked the third consecutive quarter of double-digit growth for our Analog business, and the first time we have crossed the greater than $100 million annualized revenue run rate. Those where the especially strong in the linear, interface, safety and security product lines. I was very pleased with the design wins and revenue momentum of our Analog business has shown.We continue to introduce a steady stream of innovative new products that we expect will contribute to a continued strong revenue growth in the coming quarters. Earlier this month, we announced the acquisition of ZeroG wireless, an innovator in low power wifi solutions in the embedded market that complements our broad portfolio of microcontrollers. ZeroG was a private company located in Silicon Valley and is at an early revenue stage. Now moving to Serial EE [ph] memory products this business was up 9.8% sequentially. We were pleased to see solid growth in this area for our embedded control products. We continue to run this business in a disciplined fashion that maintains consistent profitability and serves our microcontroller customers to complete their solutions. At a time when many of our competitors have significantly pushed out their lead times of between 14 and 26 weeks, Microchip's investment in inventory use the flexible rotating time-off in our factories during the recession, and ongoing operational excellence has enabled us to  continue to provide industry-leading lead times. In the current environment, this is translating to further growth in our market share as we are better able to respond to rapidly rising customer demand, capitalize on our competitor's inability to supply product as well as to instill confidence in customers who as they should commit new designs -- as to who they should commit new designs to, so that they are assured of future supply. Let me now pass it to Steve for some general comments as well as our guidance for the March quarter. Steve?

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ganesh, and good morning, everyone. Today, I would like to first reflect on the results of the December quarter, then I would answer some of the investor and analyst concerns that we have heard in the last few months, then I will talk about our
componenttext: Thank you, Ganesh, and good morning, everyone. Today, I would like to first reflect on the results of the December quarter, then I would answer some of the investor and analyst concerns that we have heard in the last few months, then I will talk about our guidance for March 2010 quarter. Reflecting on the December quarter, I want to thank the entire Microchip team for delivering an outstanding quarter in every respect. We beat the upper end of our revised guidance in the net sales, gross margins, operating profits, earnings per share and free cash flow by a significant margin. It is also the first time in over 15 years that we have achieved three consecutive quarters, with over 10% sequential growth in net sales. We also beat the lower end of our operating expense and inventory guidance by a good margin. We have now been profitable for 77 consecutive quarters and the March quarter will be our 78. From a geographical standpoint, as Eric discussed, we achieved substantial sequential growth in all major geographies of the world. And on product lines, the story was impressive too. As Ganesh discussed, we achieved significant sequential growth in all of our product lines with microcontrollers up 10%, 16-bit microcontrollers up by 10% sequentially and analog up by 14.1% sequentially. I also wanted to highlight the comparison to SIA numbers that were recently released. While Microchip does not participate in SIA, and short-term SIA numbers are often suspect, many of the investors and analysts follow those numbers. So based on this SIA data, calendar year 2009 industry sales for eight plus 16-bit microcontrollers were down 23.6% from calendar 2008. Microchip's eight plus 16-bit sales for calendar 2009 were down 14.6% from calendar 2008, so 23.6% for the industry and 14.6% for Microchip. If you look at December quarter 2009 over December quarter 2008, so last quarter over a year ago quarter, then the industry eight plus 16-bit microcontrollers sales were up 12.3% while Microchip's eight plus 16-bit MCU sales were up a whopping 29.6%. So industry at 12.3% up, and Microchip up 29.6%, showing significant market share gains. We are gaining share on both eight as well as 16-bit microcontrollers. Next, I would like to discuss four concerns that investors and analysts have raised in the last several months. The first of these concerns is where are Microchip's growth drivers? The best way to prove the growth is by posting strong sequential growth, which we have been doing for several quarters. Beyond that, there are five major drivers of growth: First, is our multi-year demand creation program, in which we added 28% additional sales and application personnel three years ago, and then we retained them through the global financial crisis of last year. They have created a steady stream of new customers and new design wins that are turning to production, adding to our growth. Second, we have an industry-leading design engineering awareness of our eight, 16 and 32-bit microcontroller solutions. On 8-bit microcontrollers, we are the number one choice of designers by a wide margin. On 16 and 32-bit, we are tied in the number first place. Number three, we have significantly expanded our served available market with the introduction of over 400 new products in the last three years, covering several key thrust areas like eXtreme Low Power, Touch Sense, USB interface, Advanced Graphics, high-performance analog, ethernet connectivity, RF connectivity, motor control and digital power supply. Number four, our Analog business is growing and gaining market share. We are gaining by attaching Analog to our microcontroller applications, as well as embedding analog functionality on the microcontroller dye.  And number five, we're gaining share from large but financially strapped competitors. The second area of concern that investors and analysts have shown is the gross margin percentage. In the earnings call in November, we shared our internal plan for calendar year '10. We gave a non-GAAP gross margin of 58.5% for the year, which was lower than our prior peak. That left the impression that gross margins are challenged. We have already exceeded that gross margin for December '09 quarter and we have guided 60% gross margin for the March 2010 quarter. We now believe that we will achieve our previous record gross margin of 61.6% non-GAAP by the end of the fiscal year '11. The third area of concern has been operating expenses. Analysts have the impression that there are large operating expenses coming that are not in the model. That is not correct. In the quarter, we just announced the operating expense was 26.2% non-GAAP, which matched the operating expense in our record quarter of fiscal Q2 '09. From September to December quarter that we just completed, our operating expenses grew by 4.3%, while sales grew by 10.3%. In the March 2010 quarter, we have all of the employee compensation programs back in the operating expenses, and we expect the operating expenses to stay in this range of 26.2% as a percentage of sales. The final concern shown has been that the inventories are getting replenished and hence, it is at the cycle top. Microchip's inventories plus our distributor's inventories combined are in the lower end of historical days of sales. We have always differentiated ourselves from the competition by maintaining some short lead times. If we could say anything about our inventory, our inventory at Microchip is lower than we would ideally like while our distribution and inventory is in a reasonable range. We are continuing to make the necessary changes to bring inventories in-line with customer's needs, and maintain the best lead times in the industry. But because of strong growth that we are experiencing, we expect inventory to really stay flat in the March quarter as Eric talked about. Having addressed these investors and analysts concerns, I will now move to provide guidance for March 2010 quarter.Our book-to-bill ratio for December quarter was 1.12, and we started the March quarter with an all-time record high backlog, so the visibility is improving significantly. The bookings rate so far in the quarter has been very strong. This quarter, we see significantly higher shipping days in U.S. and Europe, but lower shipping days in Asia because of Lunar New Year. Considering all that, we expect our net sales for the March quarter to be up between 3% and 7% sequentially above what normal seasonality is for our business. We expect our non-GAAP gross margin to be between 59.75% and 60.25%, which is 75 to 125 basis point improvement over the December quarter and we expect our GAAP gross margin to be between 58.85% and 59.35%. Regarding earnings per share for the March quarter, we expect non-GAAP earnings per share to be between $0.39 and $0.41. We expect GAAP earnings per share to be between $0.34 and $0.36. Now I would like to comment on the longer-term outlook for our calendar year '10, and this outlook for calendar year '10 excludes the acquisition of SST that we just announced. We will talk about it later. Last quarter, we shared our internal plan for calendar year '10 with investors in the financial community. We talked about calendar year '10 revenue of $1.05 billion, up 26% from calendar year '09. This internal forecast met with skepticism from several of the analysts. I'm happy to tell you that after one quarter, we see our calendar year '10 plan to be quite conservative. With just the March quarter's revenue times four, we meet our internal plan. And I've already talked about gross margin for calendar year '10 to be well above our internal plan while we won't be revising our internal plan every quarter, we are confident of beating it by a significant margin. So as we said in the start of the call, we will first take questions from investors and analysts about our earnings and our guidance. And after that, we will make some more commentary about the SST acquisition, followed by a second question-and-answers period. With that, operator, would you please pull up for questions.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question will come from the side of Uche Orji with UBS.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question will come from the side of Uche Orji with UBS.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Steve, let me just start by asking about where you are now with regards to the utilization rates? This has provided some boost to margins, obviously. If we look into playing forward, how much more upside will come from that? And also if you can talk about
componenttext: Steve, let me just start by asking about where you are now with regards to the utilization rates? This has provided some boost to margins, obviously. If we look into playing forward, how much more upside will come from that? And also if you can talk about where you see structurally margins going? In your opening remarks, you commented that you are now likely to be back by end of this year to the levels where your, let's say, peak levels. Is there any structural feeling to gross margins? Any way for us to think about where gross margins will get to? So if you can comment on some drivers, that will be helpful?

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Uche, we don't provide specific capacity utilization levels, as it just seems to create confusion with the investors and analysts. People seem to do a straight expert extrapolation and in reality, it doesn't quite work that way. We see a continued gross m
componenttext: Uche, we don't provide specific capacity utilization levels, as it just seems to create confusion with the investors and analysts. People seem to do a straight expert extrapolation and in reality, it doesn't quite work that way. We see a continued gross margin improvement in our fiscal fourth quarter based on the non-GAAP guidance we provided 59.75% to 60.25%. And we also indicated earlier that we should get back to our prior peak gross margins of 61.6% non-GAAP over the next four quarters by the end of fiscal year '11. And that gets to the prior peak gross margins, and that's where we believe that without SST, that sort of where our business model is.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: You talked about you are capitalizing on long lead times by competitor and taking share as a consequence. If you are able to place comments where by product this is happening, is this in the 8-bit or 16 bit, and also by products. If you can just give us s
componenttext: You talked about you are capitalizing on long lead times by competitor and taking share as a consequence. If you are able to place comments where by product this is happening, is this in the 8-bit or 16 bit, and also by products. If you can just give us some color as to where you are seeing the competitors struggling to meet demand, and you are seeing incremental share gains. So that would be very helpful?

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: The delivery performance from the competitors spans all the product lines, 8s, 16s and 32s. Obviously, our largest market presence is in 8-bit microcontrollers. So from a frequency standpoint, that's the most frequent place where we see that inroad happen
componenttext: The delivery performance from the competitors spans all the product lines, 8s, 16s and 32s. Obviously, our largest market presence is in 8-bit microcontrollers. So from a frequency standpoint, that's the most frequent place where we see that inroad happening. But you know, it affects more than just today's design that we can switch the microchip by helping the customer take advantage of our supply, and helping them on the technical side to make the conversion. It affects their confidence about future designs. As they look at future designs that can affect 8, 16 or 32 because when customers do their designs, they want to be able to take it to production. And they want a supplier who has a manufacturing output that lines up with what they're trying to ship.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just Steve, you reminded us that you've given a 2010 forecast early. You're not updating that per see, but you kind of alluded to the fact that you think you will. Beat that and obviously, the March guidance kind of sets the stage. As you're looking throu
componenttext: Just Steve, you reminded us that you've given a 2010 forecast early. You're not updating that per see, but you kind of alluded to the fact that you think you will. Beat that and obviously, the March guidance kind of sets the stage. As you're looking through 2010, when you think about end demand, do you think it kind of materializes in the normal seasonal fashion beyond the March quarter and whatever share gains you get on top of that? What do you think there's end markets that are still get the rebound from the inventory depletion mode they were in?

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think we have consistently said that's across our 70,000 customers and a large amount of our business coming from distribution, we don't really can break out the end demand for you by segment. Once in a while, we have done an analysis on some sample cus
componenttext: I think we have consistently said that's across our 70,000 customers and a large amount of our business coming from distribution, we don't really can break out the end demand for you by segment. Once in a while, we have done an analysis on some sample customers during the middle of the housing bust and all of that. We can create an indicator for a short period of time. But customers move around regarding where they buy their product from. Many of them switch to distributors or CMs or whatever. So our product strategy has always been very horizontal in all of our product lines. We sell across thousands of applications, 70,000 customers and we're seeing a broad-based recovery in every geography around the world. And beyond that, we can't really give you an end market commentary. We are seeing our business grow significantly better than our competitors. I did some comparisons to SIA this time in the last two or three times also. So we're seeing significant share gains, our new product pipeline is really the best it has been in a long time because we stay committed with our resources and product designs in the last year and a half for many of our competitors laid off people and killed the product pipelines. Our lead times shorter, our customer service is excellent so customers are designing with us. So we feel a very, very strong outlook in every way we look at it.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Eric, if you could just comment on the other income line the quarter-on-quarter changes we've seen, purely interest rates and how do we think about that going forward?
componenttext: And Eric, if you could just comment on the other income line the quarter-on-quarter changes we've seen, purely interest rates and how do we think about that going forward?

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's primarily driven by interest rates. We've had some longer-term investments that we had made, that has rolled off and then kind of resets it to lower rates, and what we're able to invest at today, so that is the major driver. And then going for
componenttext: Yes, that's primarily driven by interest rates. We've had some longer-term investments that we had made, that has rolled off and then kind of resets it to lower rates, and what we're able to invest at today, so that is the major driver. And then going forward, I would say that we're pretty much in a flattish modes. As we generate cash where we invest at. But the investment returns at this point in time is pretty low.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Steve, there's been a lot of dislocation in your competitive environment. I'm sure some of those guys will try to come back in the marketplace. So my questions on the design cycle. Let's say you'd take a design win and then apply in sort of other product.
componenttext: Steve, there's been a lot of dislocation in your competitive environment. I'm sure some of those guys will try to come back in the marketplace. So my questions on the design cycle. Let's say you'd take a design win and then apply in sort of other product. Do you typically keep it for the life of the product? Or do you see these guys come back next year and try to get back in.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Harsh, once a customer does the design, everybody is so resource constrained these days. Where people have laid out their resources, they will contracted them out. And once the design goes in production, we really ever seen our industry design mid protect
componenttext: Harsh, once a customer does the design, everybody is so resource constrained these days. Where people have laid out their resources, they will contracted them out. And once the design goes in production, we really ever seen our industry design mid protection switch. People switch mid-protection designs only if they can acquire the product or their significant quality and other support issues. Otherwise, the design switching usually happens on subsequent design if you give the customer then it isn't to grow away from you. In this environment, when we're actually billing customers in supplying the product with competitors at a very long lead times, the companies who are designing with us and they're favoring us, they are actually making even a stronger commitment to us going forward. Forget about growing back to the other competitors, they will keep on giving us subsequent designs because they have seen cycle after cycle, Microchip with investment and inventory in short lead times continuously gaining shares is providing them with the right product, the right functionality at the right price and at the right lead times.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's very, very broad-based. But I did highlight many of the focus areas in the last three years, where we have introduced 400 new products in the last three years. And many of these products have been in the areas of eXtreme Low Power, but I believe our
componenttext: It's very, very broad-based. But I did highlight many of the focus areas in the last three years, where we have introduced 400 new products in the last three years. And many of these products have been in the areas of eXtreme Low Power, but I believe our portfolio is about 60 or 70 products now. Touch Sense, which is really on five. We're gaining Touch Sense designs everywhere, USB interface, advanced graphics, high-performance analog, ethernet connectivity, RF, motor control and digital power supply. Some of these are highlighted and they're many, many more.

componenttext: Analog attaches to a much more than just our microcontrollers and much more than just microcontrollers in general. componenttext: I would add that 32-bit designs that take about two, two and half years to get to production because they're really on the high end. And our products have been in production less than two years. So we're sure that as you're seeing right now is still from an early-stage designs, pre-introduction alpha sites and beta sites and things like that. So the real major customer ramp we will have significant high-volume designs is really still around the corner.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: If you guys end up hitting your revenue plan for this year can just remind us of when you'll start to need to add extra capacity when your utilization rates max out in terms of quarterly revenue?
componenttext: If you guys end up hitting your revenue plan for this year can just remind us of when you'll start to need to add extra capacity when your utilization rates max out in terms of quarterly revenue?

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Again, we don't break out utilization like I said earlier, but we are continuously, incrementally adding fab capacity, bottlenecks here and there. The mix today of the products and the technology is different than the mix we had two years ago when we were
componenttext: Again, we don't break out utilization like I said earlier, but we are continuously, incrementally adding fab capacity, bottlenecks here and there. The mix today of the products and the technology is different than the mix we had two years ago when we were at the prior peak. That's why the utilization plays funny games and you guys get the wrong extrapolation because over two years, as you come back to the same peak revenue things are different and their different processes and  more advanced processes. So we are continuously, incrementally and slowly adding to the capacity to provide product for our customers at very, very short lead times. So in this coming year, as the business continues to grow, we'll be incrementally adding capital in the range that you'll see in a low capital from Microchip over the years.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010

componenttext: I guess just one additional comment on that for everybody on the call, is we have lots of floor space to grow into in the fabs and in our assembly and test operations, so it's really just equipment. And we've tried to take advantage of low-cost opportunities in the marketplace during this downturn.

componenttext: 80%, 90% of our products are still available in our fairly relatively short lead time. You always exemptions where it's a special package or a given day where a large demand came in. And those exceptions are a little more than usual now than they were nine months ago, but Microchip's lead times are really still pretty, the best in the industry.What I would like to do operator now, is to go to the next section where we will talk about SST. First, we'll make some prepared remarks and after that we'll reopen it up for questions and will take questions regarding SST. And in the second question section you can also add any of the remaining questions somebody may have regarding the earnings call.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: As most of you are aware by now, earlier today we announced the definitive agreement to acquire Silicon Storage Technology Inc. or otherwise known as SST. We're excited about this acquisition and we would now like to give you a brief overview of who SST i
componenttext: As most of you are aware by now, earlier today we announced the definitive agreement to acquire Silicon Storage Technology Inc. or otherwise known as SST. We're excited about this acquisition and we would now like to give you a brief overview of who SST is, why we decided to acquire them, how we plan to handle the financial reporting for the various SST businesses and then summarize the overall transaction. So let's start with an overview of who SST is. SST is a global leader in embedded flash technology and in licensing of these technologies. SST also has several other businesses nested within the company including Serial, Parallel and Specialty Flash Memories, 8051 microcontrollers and NAND controllers. NAND drives that provide solid state storage, power amplifiers and low noise amplifiers for Wi-Fi applications. SST is headquartered in Sunnyvale, California and has 574 employees worldwide. SST has approximately $180 million in cash and liquid trading securities on their balance sheet and no debt. We see a compelling strategic rationale to acquire SST for the following reasons: First, their proprietary Superflash technology is a critical building block technology for advanced microcontrollers. For example, this Superflash technology is licensed by most major foundries and microcontroller OEM. This acquisition secure us critical embedded flash technology for Microchip's core, Microcontroller business and it also enables us to get earlier access to advance technologies versus waiting until their in production at the foundries. This acquisition also gives us the ability to customize technology variants that would give us an advantage over competing technologies. Second, SST adds a strong patent portfolio to Microchip's intellectual property portfolio. SST is over 360 graphic patterns and over 180 patents that are pending. And third, we would add 8051 microcontrollers and NAND controllers to our microcontroller portfolio, NAND controllers essentially are specialized microcontrollers for a given application.Now let's move to the financial reporting plan. The Licensing business, 8051 microcontrollers and NAND controllers will be consolidated into Microchip's financial reporting of continuing operations. We plan to continue investing in Superflash technology, consistent with enabling our technology needs and growing the Licensing business. We plan to rationalize the Serial, Parallel and Specialty Flash Memory businesses consistent with supporting and growing the Licensing business and emulating Microchip's high margin Serial EEPROM business model. We will treat the memory business model as an asset held for sale until the rationalizing is complete. And we plan to divest the NAND drive and Wi-Fi amplifier businesses, and we'll hold them as assets held for sale.Finally, let me provide you with a transaction summary. A $2.85 per share acquisition price translates to a transaction value of $275 million. However, once you account for SST's $180 million in cash and liquid trading and securities, the net transaction value is approximately $95 million. We expect the blended, non-GAAP operating margins to be excellent after we complete the planned divestitures and rationalize the Memory business. We expect the transaction to be accretive on a non-GAAP basis in the first quarter full quarter after the transaction closes, and expect to close the transaction in the second calendar quarter of 2010. A presentation for the key points we have reviewed with you today will be available from our website after this conference call. And with that, we would be happy to take your questions about the SST acquisition.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess broader on the capital allocation front, this is, I believe the fifth acquisition you've made in the last 18 months or so. Could you just comment on  your broader strategy for capital allocation whether you have more of a divided to the acquisitio
componenttext: I guess broader on the capital allocation front, this is, I believe the fifth acquisition you've made in the last 18 months or so. Could you just comment on  your broader strategy for capital allocation whether you have more of a divided to the acquisitions right now of use of cash but rather than dividend increases, which have been a little bit measure of late?

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our dividend is still one of the highest in the industry. And as analysts, you guys should make up your mind. We have heard people say that the dividend was too high just two or three quarters ago and then for a very short period of time, we could not cov
componenttext: Our dividend is still one of the highest in the industry. And as analysts, you guys should make up your mind. We have heard people say that the dividend was too high just two or three quarters ago and then for a very short period of time, we could not cover the dividend during the global financial crisis and saying why you're paying such a high dividend. Other said their dividend will be cut, we were the one company that didn't cut it, maintained the dividend now we're slowly growing it again, still keeping it at industry high. And yes, for the last 18 months we have done five acquisitions, but most of them had been quite small. This is the largest acquisition, which will use about $95 million to $100 million. Many others have been really single-digits to low single-digits kind of numbers. So our strategy with this acquisitions is elbow out with each and every acquisition, we are slowly and steadily elbowing out to the adjacent sockets and under microcontroller or helping act to a microcontroller whether it add Wi-Fi capability to a microcontroller with ZeroG, whether it added touchscreen with the Hampshire acquisition, whether it give us the world-class C compilers with the software acquisition we did. And in this particular case, the Superflash technology, nearly 4 billion plus microcontrollers a year are built on SST flash technology, majority of our competitors and major foundries have licensed their technology. So we believe that, that technology in our hands will have significant advantage to get advance leading access to that.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: And maybe if I could ask a follow-up, specifically on SST, if you look at the designs you're at in the marketplace out there, how often does your microcontrollers appear alongside SST memory products and designs? And you expect you could also get some add
componenttext: And maybe if I could ask a follow-up, specifically on SST, if you look at the designs you're at in the marketplace out there, how often does your microcontrollers appear alongside SST memory products and designs? And you expect you could also get some additional cross-sell opportunities in addition to the advantage you mentioned before?

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: The SST memory products are not at all competitive with the Memory business we have. We make a Serial EE [Serial EEPROM] memory which is very, very low density, one 1K memory to one megabit memory. SST products are more in the area either there's serial f
componenttext: The SST memory products are not at all competitive with the Memory business we have. We make a Serial EE [Serial EEPROM] memory which is very, very low density, one 1K memory to one megabit memory. SST products are more in the area either there's serial flash or parallel flash, so their really relatively different market. We have not seen these products very much around the microcontroller, although when you get into large customers, large blue-chip customers they use everything, then we'll find some opportunities. But the goal with the SST business and the memory is not necessarily to ship more of those memory products around microcontrollers but to actually rationalize the large memory business so it makes a high profits like our Serial Memory business.

componenttext: I think the answer is yes. They have a high exposure into the consumer segment than into the PC segment. As Steve mentioned, I think what we want to understand is how we can find the aspects of the business that have margin characteristics that we would like, and that's really where we will focus our energies on.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me expand on that. Take the Microcontroller Touch business, competitors focus on handsets. We have a large touch business with 500 customers in production, largely outside of the handsets making very high margins. Serial EE business, most of our compe
componenttext: Let me expand on that. Take the Microcontroller Touch business, competitors focus on handsets. We have a large touch business with 500 customers in production, largely outside of the handsets making very high margins. Serial EE business, most of our competitors take the low margin businesses in PC consumer, whatever. We have a highly profitable good margin Serial EE business. So this is the Microchip strength and skill, where we know how to draw the diamond out of the rough, and that's what we got to do with this business.
